title: Mathematics Instructional Design Strategies Through Educational Technology Role Exploration: Computation, Formula, and Equation-Centered Approaches

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of elementary mathematics curriculum and basic instructional design principles, foundational formula calculation, and graph interpretation skills
context.additional_context: Blended environment combining smartphone-based online learning and offline workshops. Pre-service teachers critically analyze the role of educational technology and explore its application in math classes. Emphasizes problem-solving activities (e.g., equation solving, data visualization) and collaborative learning strategies using digital tools

learning_goals: Cultivating critical analysis skills regarding the functions of educational technology based on debates among major educational theorists, while evaluating the effectiveness of technology use in solving math problems and interpreting graphs
Designing strategies to promote active learner participation in technology-based math learning environments, integrating digital tools into equation-solving and statistical analysis activities

Learners can compare three or more math learning methods (e.g., flipped learning, blended learning, AI-based personalized learning), write a report analyzing their pros/cons, and propose two technology-integrated solutions considering educational constraints (time, budget, tech accessibility) (e.g., probability simulation tools, interactive geometry software)

Clearly defining the teacher’s role in technology-integrated lesson design, developing assessment tools, and establishing formative evaluation methods to enhance understanding of math concepts (e.g., functions, measurement, proofs)

constraints.tech_requirements: Limited tech environment (no PC, smartphone only)

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
